data.title: Jazz Listings for June 15
data.meta_description: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York.
data.text:
Jazz

Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz.

★ GERI ALLEN AND CARRIE MAE WEEMS (Friday) Ms. Allen, the erudite postbop pianist, and Ms Weems, the esteemed photographer and video artist, have joined forces to create “Slow Fade to Black,” a multimedia performance touching on issues of race and gender, with a range of musical settings. In addition to two of her working bands, the Geri Allen Trio and Timeline, Ms. Allen brings in the vocalists Lizz Wright and Patrice Rushen; the Howard University vocal ensemble Afro Blue; the bassist-singer Esperanza Spalding; the drummer Teri Lyne Carrington; and the tap dancer Maurice Chestnut. At 8 p.m., Celebrate Brooklyn! at the Prospect Park Bandshell, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 683-5600, bricartsmedia.org; $3 suggested donation. (Nate Chinen)

Omer Avital & the Band of the East (Tuesday) Mr. Avital, an Israeli bassist drawn to knockabout rhythm, has an engaging new album, “Suite of the East” (Anzic), that reflects his global vision. He leads a different version of that group here, with Itamar Borochov on trumpet, Greg Tardy on tenor saxophone, Nadav Remez on guitar and Johnathan Blake on drums. From 8:30 to 11 p.m., Smalls Jazz Club, 183 West 10th Street, West Village, (212) 252-5091, smallsjazzclub.com; $20 cover. (Chinen)

Peter Bernstein Quartet (Tuesday through June 24) Peter Bernstein, a guitarist with a clean tone and unwavering technique, leads a postbop combo with the pianist Donald Vega, the bassist Dwayne Burno and the drummer Bill Stewart, a longtime collaborator. At 9 and 11 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037, villagevanguard.com; $25 cover, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen)

★ Terence Blanchard (Wednesday through June 24) In certain circles Terence Blanchard may be best known as an accomplished film scorer and a newly established Broadway composer; around the jazz ecosystem he’s known for his trenchant trumpet playing, and for favoring a postbop sound informed by myriad sources. His influential working band plays music not only by Mr. Blanchard but also by most of its bright younger members, including the saxophonist Brice Winston, the pianist Fabian Almazan and the drummer Kendrick Scott. At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; $35 cover. (Chinen)

★ The Checkout: Live From 92YTribeca Featuring Clarence Penn / Antonio Sanchez (Saturday) Mr. Penn and Mr. Sanchez are two of the busier and more fluently adaptable drummers on the jazz landscape, and each has begun to make a mark as a bandleader. For this double bill, presented by 92YTriBeCa and “The Checkout,” a program on WBGO-FM (88.3), Mr. Penn will work with the saxophonist Seamus Blake, the guitarist Adam Rogers and the bassist Ben Street. Mr. Sanchez will lead a version of Migration, his dynamic postbop band. At 9 p.m., 92YTriBeCa, 200 Hudson Street, at Canal Street, (212) 601-1000, 92ytribeca.org; $12 in advance, $15 on day of the show. (Chinen)

Kris Davis Trio (Friday) An inquisitive pianist with a willful but methodical approach to experimentation, Kris Davis has made herself indispensable on New York’s left-of-center jazz scene in recent years. She has top-flight accompaniment here, from the bassist Michael Formanek and the drummer Nasheet Waits. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; $10 cover, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)
